question: Look, I know he's there, so quit lying to me!... Then check under Lana Holden -- Mrs. Lana Holden... Fine. Just tell Lieutenant Demetras that his wife called and -- Ma!
answer: No. I want you to listen to me. You can't keep doing this to yourself -- or to the boys. They need their mother now. You're a beautiful, talented woman and you have your whole life ahead of you.

question: If I'm so beautiful and talented, why did Charles leave me?
answer: Because Charles is a big jerk. Now get dressed.

question: You really think Charles is a jerk?
answer: From the day you married him.

question: Why didn't you say something?
answer: Since when do you listen to me?

question: What am I gonna do?
answer: First, you eat breakfast. Second, you go out and get a job -- any job. Your boys, god-bless-em, are good eaters -- but I can't afford it.

question: Mama, he's gonna get tired of her -- you'll see.
answer: Well in the meantime, get a job.

question: Brian Turner?
answer: Hello, Roberta.

question: I thought you moved away.
answer: I did. I'm in town for my Mom's birthday. No -- that's her gift.

question: Oh! Sorry.
answer: It looks very pretty.

question: Thank you. I heard you had a book published. I didn't read it but...
answer: That's O.K. My parents didn't read it either. It looks good on their coffee table, though. So what are you doing here? I thought you'd be in Carnegie Hall by now.

question: My college professors said it was too late -- I hadn't had enough training to be a concert violinist. So I got a teaching degree instead.
answer: I'll bet you're a great teacher.

question: I think I am. It's just that... See, every time I'd get started somewhere, Charles would be transferred... then I had my kids and took time off to raise them... and then when I decided to teach again, no one would hire me 'cause you can't count on a navy wife to stick around. I finally decided I'd start my own program -- Charles gave me the money and I bought fifty violins from this little Greek shop -- got started at a private school and then...
answer: Your husband ran off with your best friend.

question: She wasn't my "best" friend. She was a friend. Charles is the last person you'd think would cheat on me -- he never broke a rule... I wake up one night -- it's like one in the morning -- and he's not in bed. I go outside and our neighbor -- this old Greek guy -- is sitting out there, smoking a cigar, so I ask if he's seen my husband. "He's taking a walk with the other officer's wife," he says. "He takes a walk every night with the other officer's wife." God, these are cold.
answer: So you're just gonna wrap presents and wait for him to come back?

question: You sound like my mother.
answer: That's not very sexy.

question: Are you trying to be sexy or be my friend?
answer: A little of both. You know, I know this really cool lady who runs this elementary school -- I wrote a piece on her. It's a public school, but it's alternative -- she might be able to create some kind of gig for you. Let me give her a call.

question: Great!
answer: If she hires you, though, you have to be willing to relocate.

question: Where is it?
answer: Aside from half a term in a private school -- in Greece -- and a year teaching chorus in Hawaii -- ten years ago -- it doesn't look like you've had any other teaching experience.

question: Well, not traditional teaching experience. I've been doing private lessons... It's not on there... I taught my sons.
answer: I'd like to help you, Mrs. Demetras. Brian spoke highly of you and I told him I'd consider starting a violin class... But without the proper qualifications, and without any experience in an inner city school... I'm very sorry. Yes?

question: I'm sorry to interrupt, but I wanted you to meet my sons -- Nick, Lexi... Roberta Guaspari-Demetras.
answer: This is Dennis Rausch, our music teacher and program coordinator. Mrs. Demetras, didn't I make things clear yesterday?

question: They don't have to. If they can help, great -- but these kids will be committed. They'll practice on their own, they'll help each other in the classroom --
answer: I think I know these students, Miss Demetras. Their attention span doesn't go past do-re-mi. Maybe on a good day, I can get them to "fa."

question: You're underestimating them. They can play as well as any other kids.
answer: That I'd like to see.

question: Please do not open the cases, O.K.? Look, can everyone just settle down and listen to me -- please? Keep them closed! Please. Did you hear what I just said? Put those down, please! Don't do that! Put the bows back in the cases -- right now! Who's plucking? What have I been saying? Put that away! Back in the case! O.K. Thank you. That's much better. I'll be dividing you into five classes, but for today -- O.K. -- that's it! You! Stand up! You will be the first student who will NOT be in my violin class. Out! I said OUT! Who else would like to be kicked out of my class? Are you raising your hand because you want to be kicked out?
answer: Yeah.

question: Why?
answer: I don't wanna learn no stupid violin. It's for wimps.

question: Who told you that?
answer: I just know.

question: Well, De Sean -- you haven't given me a good enough reason, so you're staying. Anyone else?
answer: Hey, I play pretty good.

question: See how easy it is? Maybe in the spring, we could have a big concert for your families and for the whole school. What's your name?
answer: Naeem.

question: If you listen to me and do exactly what I say, you're gonna sound beautiful at the concert and you're gonna be so proud of yourselves. Good, Naeem. Your hand's staying soft. But if you don't listen to me, you'll sound so bad that your own parents will feel sick when they hear you. They might even throw up. Come in. What's this?
answer: It's a toast. To Roberta, who's made it through her first week.

question: I don't know, Brian. I'm hanging on by a thread there. Out of fifty kids, maybe six are listening to me.
answer: Look at the progress. Didn't you say no one was listening to you on Monday?

question: I really appreciate all you've done for us. And I promise -- this weekend I'll start looking for a place.
answer: There's no rush.

question: No, we've put you out enough. You're supposed to be writing, not babysitting for us. I've started your book. It's very powerful.
answer: Thank you.

question: So what made you choose migrant workers for your next book? I mean, how do you know what to write about?
answer: I follow my gut, pay attention to what I'm being drawn to...

question: What are you doing?
answer: I've been waiting to do that since Mr. Baines' orchestra class.

question: You didn't even notice me!
answer: Sure I did. You used to ignore me and it drove me wild.

question: You had at least five different girlfriends.
answer: It didn't mean I had the one I wanted. You're not a navy wife anymore...

question: Yes I am... legally.
answer: And is it a navy requirement that you dress like it's the 1950's?

question: I do not!
answer: Who did you vote for in the last election?

question: What does that have to do with anything?
answer: Tell me.

question: I don't know. Charles filled out my absentee ballot.
answer: Oh my God -- it's even worse than I thought! Is this the same Roberta who got the orchestra to strike until they gave us new uniforms?

question: That Roberta's not around anymore.
answer: I don't believe that.

question: I shouldn't.
answer: Because?

question: The boys --
answer: They're sleeping.

question: I know, but... I'm still married.
answer: And what's your husband doing right now?

question: Oh shit -- the boys.
answer: They're still sleeping.

question: Where are you going?
answer: Texas.

question: What's in Texas?
answer: Farm workers. I just got the call -- it came through -- my research grant! It came through! Isn't that great?

question: Today?
answer: I've got a few families lined up there, some in California --

question: How long will you be gone?
answer: Two, three months.

question: What? I thought... I just thought you were gonna be around. And then last night --
answer: Whoa. Roberta -- last night was great but did you think I was gonna marry you in the morning?

question: No! Of course not. It's just that... we just got here and we're barely... I don't even know where to buy groceries.
answer: You're gonna be fine. You have a job, a place to stay, your kids have a school to go to -- and there's a D'Agostino's around the corner.

question: And what do we call this? De Sean?
answer: Yeah?

question: What do we call this?
answer: I don't know.

question: Why not?
answer: I wasn't here.

question: C-C-C-C, D-D-D-D, E-E-E-E...
answer: Excuse me -- sorry to interrupt --

question: No talking!
answer: I'm supposed to take kids out of Miss Cooper's classroom for my ten o'clock class -- there's nobody there.

question: Miss Cooper's students have phys ed on Tuesdays.
answer: But you scheduled them for violin.

question: You must have read the schedule wrong.
answer: I don't think so.

question: Well, I can't solve this problem for you right now. I'm trying to teach.
answer: So am I.

question: Honey, we don't have a puppy.
answer: Daddy said we could get one when we moved back to America.

question: How about your truck? I'll bet you're the only one in school with a truck from Greece.
answer: When's Daddy coming back?

question: Where were you today, Naeem?
answer: I can't be in violin class anymore.

question: Why not?
answer: My mother won't let me.

question: What?
answer: My son's got more important things to do than learn dead white men's music.

question: They're gonna learn "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star"!
answer: How many Black classical composers can you name? How many Black classical violinists do you know?

question: Knock it off, De Sean! If you kids can't take this seriously, I don't want you here. I'm teaching you a difficult instrument because I respect you and have faith that you can learn it. But none of that matters if you don't have respect for yourself. Now turn your wrist so it's flat against the fingerboard, and that's how you'll set up your hand... Guadalupe! You've got the violin in the wrong hand! How did that happen? Hello?
answer: Hello, Bobbi.

question: Where are you?
answer: I'm back in the States. I'm at my parents.

question: Are you still with her?
answer: No.

question: We've missed you so much, Charles. The boys... they can't wait for you to come home... I know we'll have a lot to work out and it won't be easy right away, but we're gonna get through this, you know? We're a family and we belong together and --
answer: Bobbi -- stop, O.K.? Just stop. I want a divorce.

question: What? But you said... you and Lana... you said it was over.
answer: It is. It's over between us too, Bobbi.

question: He wouldn't even talk about it! No explanations, no discussion...
answer: I can't believe you were still holding out hope. The guy hasn't called you or the kids in three months -- I thought you'd moved on.

question: I never said that.
answer: No? Maybe not with words.

question: You know what? I shouldn't have called you. This was a mistake.
answer: No, no -- I'm sorry. Look, I know it hurts, but you're gonna get through this, Roberta -- you will.

question: I'm moving back to my Mom's.
answer: What? You're gonna quit teaching in the middle of the term?

question: I don't fit in there -- I'm not making any progress with the kids...
answer: What are you gonna tell Janet -- your husband left you and nothing else matters?

question: My mother gave it to me.
answer: Why would she give you fifty dollars?

question: To buy breakfast.
answer: Do you know how hard your mother works? Do you think it's right for you steal from her?

question: I didn't!
answer: Well let's go call her right now and ask her.

question: Guadalupe? What are you doing here?
answer: I can't get the stop sign.

question: Honey, your teacher's probably looking for you.
answer: I can't come anymore. It's too hard.

question: The violin is hard for everyone.
answer: But everyone else is better than me. I'll always be slow.

question: Did you ever hear of Itzhak Perlman?
answer: No.

question: He's one of the greatest violinists in the world, and he has problems with his legs too. He walks with two canes -- but he still makes the most beautiful music.
answer: And he sits down when he plays?

question: He has to.
answer: He was your student?

question: No. But if he was, I'd tell him the same thing I'm telling you. You shouldn't quit something just because it's hard.
answer: But I can't stand strong.

question: That is so beautiful!
answer: Whatsa matter -- you got cooties?

question: Apparently.
answer: I'll take my chances. Isabel Vasquez. Second grade.

question: Roberta Demetras. I'm the --
answer: Violin teacher. I know.

question: Is it my imagination, or does everyone hate me?
answer: It's hard to fit in when you're doing a special program. People figure you're not gonna be here very long, so why make the effort? It may take a while for folks to warm up, but nobody hates you.

question: What about Alice Crowley?
answer: A) she thinks the violin's a waste of time... and B) -- she's a bitch.

question: And then there's Dennis.
answer: The Music Man. You've had the bodacity to threaten his private little empire -- not to mention the fact that you messed up his sacred scheduling chart.

question: How come you're being nice to me?
answer: Ulterior motives. I want my daughter in your class next year.

question: If I'm here next year.
answer: You will be.

question: In Greece, we could see the ocean. Remember?
answer: I remember. And the fishing boats...

question: And the octopuses. Is Daddy coming here soon?
answer: Well, that's something I've been wanting to talk to you about. Daddy's not gonna live with us anymore. You and Lexi will have special times when you stay with him, like at Christmas.

question: Can you tell the birthday story?
answer: Don't you want to talk about what I told you?

question: I want to hear the birthday story.
answer: It was the day of Grandpa's birthday, and I was sad because he had died a few months back.

question: But you knew I'd be born that day.
answer: So I packed a bag and got all ready --

question: And Daddy laughed.
answer: I said, "It's my father's birthday, and the baby's gonna be born today."

question: He didn't believe you. But I was born. The same day as Grandpa.
answer: It was a happy day.

question: Was Daddy happy too?
answer: Of course he was.

question: Then why is he leaving me?
answer: He's not leaving you, Nick. He loves you and Lexi very much.

question: Then why can't he live here?
answer: It's very hard to explain... Sometimes things happen between grown-ups... and they just can't be together.

question: Slow bows! Slow bows! Don't squeeze! Stop! Everybody stop! How much did you practice this week?
answer: My asthma -- it was very bad and I had to go to the hospital.

question: Again? You told me you went to the hospital last week.
answer: Oh yeah. Maybe it was last week.

question: Lucy -- you sounded the worst of all. Have you practiced?
answer: No.

question: Why not? You can't be in this class if you don't practice!
answer: My grandma got mugged.

question: Oh. I'm sorry. Is she O.K.?
answer: She died.

question: That's O.K. Why don't you go grab one of my spare violins? Let's try it again. What are you playing?
answer: Twinkle.

question: Everyone stop! Let me hear. Did someone teach you that?
answer: No. I made it up.

question: Well, that was... that was pretty good... that wasn't too bad...
answer: It wasn't? I thought we stunk.

question: I wouldn't put it that way... You all just need to practice a bit more. James, have you practiced this week? Can you please try a little harder for next week? Good. Just do the best you can.
answer: Why you acting like that?

question: Like what?
answer: Nice.

question: Don't you want a nice teacher?
answer: I already got nice teachers. You added some variety.

question: I've noticed. I still don't understand the rush.
answer: Having my own place will make me feel like I'm really starting my life again.

question: But if you invested your divorce settlement, you could buy something nice someday. It's bad enough that you've been renting in this neighborhood, but to lock yourself into a mortgage --
answer: Mama, please. Just stop! Don't worry, O.K.? Besides, if things keep going well, I'm sure eventually Brian will move in with us.

question: How much do you know about this man?
answer: Brian's a good person, he's helped me a lot, he's great with the boys -- since he got back to town, it's been really sweet.

question: And how long has he been back?
answer: Two months.

question: That's not very long. Don't make the same mistake twice, Bert. You barely knew Charles when you married him.
answer: I don't get it -- you're ragging on me about buying the house -- I would think you'd want Brian to live with me.

question: That's not a very nice thing to say about your classmates. How many people think they can get it right by the concert? I love you. Did you just laugh?
answer: I'm sorry. It's just...

question: What?
answer: Why do people feel like the minute something's going great, they gotta name it? Once you name something, you snuff the life out of it.

question: Jesus, Brian. Do you still get away with that crap? It's not the Sixties anymore.
answer: Well, maybe if you'd actually gone through the Sixties, you'd know what I'm talking about.

question: Fine! We won't name it, we won't talk about it, we'll act like we have no feelings for each other whatsoever!
answer: I'm sorry. I'm being an asshole. You can say you love me if you want.

question: Forget it. I changed my mind. How's it coming, Ernie?
answer: You're crazy. Why did you hire him?

question: He needed a job. Besides, he's wired all of East Harlem.
answer: When? Fifty years ago?

question: Why is there wallpaper on it?
answer: What the hell is this?

question: Sheetrock.
answer: You've gotta be kidding. Those ex- cons you hired ripped this off -- and you too!

question: Look -- this house is taking every penny of my settlement. I can't afford fancy union workers!
answer: Fine. Do it your way.

question: I'm giving him a two-day suspension -- but next time he'll be expelled.
answer: There won't be a next time -- I promise.

question: Have you noticed your son lately? He's tied up in knots and he needs help.
answer: Janet, kids fight. You're making too much of this.

question: He was choking the kid. Nick's in trouble, Roberta. You need to deal with it.
answer: Keep playing, guys. You can watch when we're done.

question: Keep playing, guys. You can watch when we're done.
answer: It's my house! They don't live here -- I do!

question: Nick honey -- the kids are real nervous about the Spring concert. You could probably give them some pointers.
answer: I don't feel like it.

question: Good catch Nick! Uh-oh. You know what that means?
answer: Don't! Don't throw me in!

question: Whatsa matter? Afraid of a little water? The ducks aren't afraid! Are you a chicken or a duck?
answer: Don't! Don't throw me!

question: Looks like you got yourself a chicken, Roberta!
answer: I'm not a chicken!

question: You seem to be the only one who can get Nick to laugh these days.
answer: He misses his dad. I'm just a surrogate.

question: No -- I think Nick really likes you. You know... we're all hoping you'll move into the new house with us.
answer: Whoa. Can we just slow down here a minute? It's too much like getting married.

question: What's so bad about that?
answer: That kind of commitment just isn't realistic. I mean, how can we know that you and I will even be able to stand each other in five years?

question: Well, we don't. But if two people care about each other, they take a chance.
answer: And look what happened to you and Charles.

question: I'm not talking about Charles. I'm talking about us.
answer: Look, Roberta. Marriage is based on a belief that one person can completely meet another person's needs. I just don't buy that.

question: What are you saying? If there's some need you have that I don't meet, you'd go and get it "met" by someone else?
answer: I'm saying that it's the 80's and it's a fantasy to think of marriage lasting these days. One out of two marriages ends in divorce!

question: You didn't answer my question. If I don't meet all your needs, and we're in a committed relationship -- forget marriage for a minute; I'm just talking about a relationship -- would you go to someone else?
answer: In theory, yes.

question: In theory.
answer: Roberta, we've got something good right now -- that's the important thing. Let's just keep it that way, O.K.?

question: Why can't he?
answer: He just can't, O.K.? Brian's at his house tonight, and we're at ours.

question: Well then I wanna go to his house.
answer: Enough, Nick. Now why don't you and your brother practice while I make dinner.

question: I don't feel like practicing.
answer: Well do it anyway.

question: I wanna go to Brian's!
answer: Stop whining, and get your violin. What the hell are you doing?

question: The problem with you is you're mean to everybody and then they don't want to be with you!
answer: I've heard just about enough from you, young man. Now set your violin up properly and start practicing.

question: I hate the violin!
answer: You pick that violin up right now and don't you ever ever --

question: It's all your fault! You made Daddy leave and you're gonna make Brian leave too! You're gonna be all alone and I'll have to take care of you!
answer: Nick -- you don't have to take care of me.

question: Then who's going to?
answer: I'll take care of myself -- and I'll take care of you and Lexi. I promise.

question: You didn't try hard enough. You made Daddy leave us.
answer: That's not true. I begged him not to leave, but he didn't listen.

question: Why not?
answer: Your father met someone he liked more than Mommy, and then --

question: Who?
answer: Lana. Remember our friends Lana and Tom?

question: Is he gonna marry her now?
answer: No, but he's not coming back... to me. I'll take care of you, Nick. You too, Lexi. I promise. I'm not going anywhere. We're still a family. I promise.

question: What color is this? I told you Eggshell.
answer: You're an idiot! I told you -- you can't be your own contractor.

question: You're right. I'm an idiot. Wake up, Ernie. You're fired. You're fired. You're fired.
answer: That's more like it.

question: You're fired too. No, Brian. I mean it. I need to be with a man who can make a commitment to me. I need that, and my sons need that. So can you?
answer: Roberta --

question: Vibrato... don't wiggle your wrist.
answer: Dang! I can't get that right.

question: You almost have it.
answer: Almost isn't good enough.

question: Did I turn you into such a perfectionist?
answer: No. I came that way.

question: Just as long as you get it right for your Julliard audition.
answer: What?

question: No. But I keep trying. And maybe someday the school will give me a parking space!
answer: Wait --

question: God, these are great.
answer: Those copies are for you.

question: Thank you. Can I... pay for you them?
answer: Don't be silly. Besides -- you'll need your money for parking tickets. What you're doing for these children is wonderful. My husband's a violinist -- he was quite impressed when I told him about you.

question: What's his name?
answer: Arnold Steinhardt.

question: Of the Guarneri String Quartet?
answer: Stay in touch. Let us know when the kids have a concert.

question: Amanda, what did I tell you about wearing cowboy boots to violin class? They're too slippery! Relax your two, Simon... Your stop sign has to be up, Kenny! Stephanie, it doesn't look like you ever had a lesson with me! Where's your violin, Carlos?
answer: It's coming.

question: What, is it walking here by itself? Your buddies giving you a hard time?
answer: Look, it's just not cool. You wouldn't understand.

question: Hey, you want your sister to carry your violin, that's fine. But is she practicing for you too? Because lately, that's how it sounds.
answer: I've been busy! I've been --

question: Ramon, I don't like that kind of talk. Justin, pick up his stand, now! Our spring concert is in three weeks and you might not be in it. Is that what you want? Mr. Klein? I'm gonna have to drop Vanessa from the class if she keeps forgetting her violin. Oh. I'm sorry. Vanessa, maybe you could write down for your Mom and Dad which days are violin days.
answer: The tape doesn't stick.

question: What?
answer: I taped the music to the wall at my Mom's house and then I took it to my Dad's house and it doesn't stick anymore.

question: Roberta! Come in.
answer: I came by to check on Ramon.

question: Why?
answer: Didn't he tell you what happened at school?

question: Did that sound O.K.?
answer: Yeah, it did. I've been thinking about Justin. Remember how mad I got the last time I saw him?

question: Yeah. You got very strict with him.
answer: It wasn't always so easy to be nice to him, you know?

question: You think Justin's in heaven or hell?
answer: Heaven.

question: I told him to drop dead.
answer: Justin didn't die because of what you said. I promise.

question: How do you know?
answer: I don't think you're that powerful, do you? I mean, if you had such powers, just imagine what kind of violin player you'd be by now!

question: Yeah. I'd be better than you!
answer: It's O.K. to cry, you know.

question: Not for a man.
answer: My boys still cry and they're big, strong young men now. I bet Justin's daddy cried. Nick, Lexi! Get down here right now!

question: My boys still cry and they're big, strong young men now. I bet Justin's daddy cried. Nick, Lexi! Get down here right now!
answer: We were just trying to help!

question: This is humiliating!
answer: Mom, no one knows it's you! I mean, you don't even have to read them if you don't want to. Although obviously, a lot of guys are interested in dating you.

question: No. A lot of guys are interested in dating you and Lexi. What did you say about me, anyway?
answer: "Beautiful musician, late 40's, tired of playing solo --

question: Make sure you're home by midnight, young lady.
answer: Ten bucks he tries to kiss her.

question: That's a no-brainer. Of course he'll try. The real question is whether she'll let him.
answer: O.K. -- ten bucks she lets him.

question: I had a lot of fun tonight.
answer: Yeah, I did too.

question: I have a confession -- I've never answered an ad before. I did it on a dare.
answer: Well, I have a confession -- my boys placed the ad behind my back. Look, Dan -- I went along with this 'cause it's been a while. Quite a while... And I had a very nice time... but I'm not sure if I'm ready to get involved with anyone right now.

question: Does this mean I don't get any lasagna?
answer: Why are you guys still up?

question: Well... he's nice.
answer: "Nice"? As in "let's just be friends" nice?

question: I don't know yet. We'll see.
answer: There's still a lot more letters.

question: What?! Is it true?
answer: Why don't you come in my office?

question: It's true? You're firing me?
answer: It's not me, Roberta. The Board of Ed. cut the budget, the District had to comply, and as of the end of this term, the violin program has been... excessed.

question: Excessed. They specifically said that my violin program has to go.
answer: They've slashed the budget -- music and art programs got hit the worst.

question: Shut up, Dennis! You're not helping! Come into my office, please.
answer: There's gotta be a way to fight this!

question: Fight it with what? I don't have any other extra programs to give them instead.
answer: Oh, I see. So after ten years, after fourteen hundred children have learned to play the violin, this is just an "extra program."

question: You know I don't feel that way and you know damn well I've been standing by you all these years! You think I haven't noticed what you've done for these kids?
answer: Then do something!

question: It's like when my father got killed. For twenty years, he followed every safety rule the factory had, and then someone else flips the wrong switch... It's not fair. You do everything right and then...
answer: It's the wrong analogy. You couldn't do anything about Grandpa's death. It was irreversible. This isn't.

question: Tell that to the Board of Education.
answer: Let me ask you something. Why did you risk your life for a bicycle?

question: I did not risk my life.
answer: Of course you did! That building? Threatening Henry? And for what -- two hundred dollars?

question: Ma!
answer: I would too. Sorry I'm early, but I figured we'd need time to set up.

question: Mama, why don't you take Allegra out for a walk?
answer: You are having a meeting here tonight, right? Parents and teachers?

question: Well, yes, but ...
answer: Take it from me. If you want to get parents to help you with something, you have to feed them. You have a cutting board for these? And if you think parents are bad, teachers are even worse, no offense. If you don't feed them, you never get anything extra out of them. That's why I got this. Entenmann's gets them every time. What? Don't tell me you expected me to bring something homemade.

question: Well, no... I --
answer: Good. Because take it from me -- my own family begs me to stay out of the kitchen.

question: What I didn't expect was for you to be here.
answer: Why not? We've gotta figure out a way to fight this. After ten years, Roberta, I can't imagine walking through those hallways and not hearing that off-key, screechy, scratchy, nails-on-the- blackboard violin music. What do you think? Cut it into slices now, or leave it whole?

question: What if you do a benefit concert? We can raise a batch of money from ticket sales, and then the concert itself could be great publicity. There's word of mouth... you could get reviewed...
answer: It better be a good concert! We have to offer something more than me and the kids. Do you think maybe your husband would perform with us?

question: I'm sure I could persuade him with a little pillow talk. And maybe he can get another violinist too -- Itzhak Perlman, perhaps.
answer: That would be fantastic.

question: Kids, listen to me -- it's really important that you don't look at the camera and you try to act as natural as possible.
answer: Who authorized this?

question: Janet.
answer: Well Janet's not here today and I want these people out of here. Turn that off, you hear me?

question: Why are you doing this? We're not bothering anyone.
answer: You're disrupting school and I want them out of here -- now.

question: You still don't get it, do you? I don't care if you hate me, Dennis -- that's your business. But think about the students for once. Every time you interfere, you're not hurting me -- you're hurting them.
answer: Get these people out of here or I'm calling the police.

question: There's no time to be tired. Let's try it again. I must have been crazy to agree to this. They're never gonna be ready. And you should hear the Bach Double! A disaster. So the good news is tickets are selling like hot cakes, but the bad news is that the kids sound like shit.
answer: There's more bad news... We've lost the Y.

question: What?!
answer: They had a flood -- a water heater burst... The concert hall was damaged and they've cancelled all events.

question: Until when?
answer: "Until further notice."

question: This can't happen! We've sold tickets! We've done publicity! The concert's in three weeks!
answer: I've been on the phone all morning calling other theaters. Nothing's available.

question: Itzhak and Arnold are booked all summer.
answer: It's Dorothea. I have good news -- really good news. Arnold got a call from his friend Wally Scheur who heard about us losing the Y and wanted to see how he could help -- and then Wally had this brilliant idea and called his friend Isaac Stern and it's all arranged! We have a new place for Fiddlefest!

question: Where?
answer: Carnegie Hall.

question: Carnegie Hall? Oh my god -- Isaac Stern.
answer: You must be Roberta.

question: Thank you so much for helping us.
answer: Would you believe in 1960, they tried to tear this place down? They wanted to replace it with a bright red skyscraper -- we called it "the red terror."

question: You're kidding.
answer: We had to fight like hell, but with a lot of help, we saved Carnegie Hall. If it's all right with you, I'd like to play in your concert. Maybe bring a couple of friends...

question: Yes, of course! That would be great!
answer: Don't give up.

question: I just don't see how I'm gonna do this. It's huge. It's gigantic! It's Carnegie Hall! And listen to this
answer: That's fantastic!

question: Fantastic? I'll never get the kids up to speed in time, I'll never get myself up to speed. I'm gonna be playing side by side with the world's greatest violinists.
answer: And "the world's greatest violinists" are playing side by side with you because they want to help you win this fight.

question: Yes, but... you don't understand. Maybe there's a good reason why I never made it as a violinist -- maybe I just can't cut it. I keep blaming it on not having enough early training, but if I were talented, if I had a gift --
answer: But you do have a gift. You're gonna put thirty East Harlem kids on stage at Carnegie Hall not because they're prodigies, but because you got them to stick with something that's hard as hell and to strive for excellence -- which, by the way, I certainly wasn't striving for when I was their age. Not to mention the other ten years' worth of students whose lives were changed because of you. That's your talent, Roberta.

question: I'm scared.
answer: I know. And by the way, I happen to think you're a pretty good violinist too.

question: You've barely heard me play.
answer: I've heard enough to know you're gonna do just fine. Besides, no one's gonna be paying attention to your playing anyway.

question: He's right, by the way. You do sound terrible, and you are gonna make everyone in Carnegie Hall sick to their stomachs.
answer: I need to talk to you.

question: I'll be right in. Start on Minuet One. What's wrong?
answer: We're moving away.

question: What? Where are you moving?
answer: It's a secret... My father... he's been hurting my mom... We have to leave.

question: Has he been hurting you too?
answer: I'm sorry about Julliard... and the concert.

question: Keep it. Take it with you.
answer: No... I don't want to play anymore.

question: What?! You can't give up violin, Rachel -- it's a part of you. A very important part. Please honey. Just take it.
answer: I don't want to.

question: Thank you, Mama.
answer: Don't worry about it. You rip -- I sew.

question: Not just for that. Thank you for getting me out of bed.
answer: Don't thank me -- thank Charles.

question: Charles?!
answer: If that jerk hadn't of left you, none of this would've happened.
